answers.answer: Your symptoms could be related to your heart, especially, the fatigue, the nausea and the lightheadedness if your heart suffered a large heart attack.  The way your would know that would be from an echocardiogram, specifically, the ejection fraction.  It it is normal, close to normal, or even moderately depressed, you should not have these symptoms from your heart.  These symptoms could also be related to other conditions and also to the medications you are taking.  The conditions worth looking into include commonly Diabetes and hypothyroidism.  The coreg could make you lightheaded if you are on too much of it.  The vytorin and the aspirin could give you nausea.  The vytorin could also give you muchscle aches.  The only way to tell if your arteries are blocking up more is by worsening symptoms of chest pain or exertional dyspnea or by a catheterization.  It does't sound like you are having those symptoms, therefore, I wouldn't worry about that.  More importantly, it is imperative that you take your medications because all the long term benefits come from them.   If the ones that you are on are truely giving you some side-effects as you have described than your doctor should switch you to an alternate medication.  Sounds like you should sit down with your cardiologist and go over all these issues.

question: I had a sudden death heart attack 6 years ago. I am on aspirin, vytorin, coreg,trimed, fish oil and xanex.  I always feel very tired, and most days feel nausea, and light headed. Also lots of muscle aches of moderate intensity. Is this from all the medicine I am taking, or would it indicate other heart problems?  I am 57 years old, exercise some and watch my diet regularly. I sometimes think that my arteries are blocking up even more, but no one seems to have an answer. Does anyone else have these symptoms???
title: heart
